<compliance_report>
    <compliance_issues>
        <issue priority="MATERIAL" confidence="85">
            <title>Missing Administrative Regulation for Implementation Procedures</title>
            <description>While the Board Policy establishes the framework for employee technology use, there is no corresponding Administrative Regulation to provide detailed implementation procedures. California school districts typically require both policy (board direction) and regulation (implementation procedures) for comprehensive technology use governance. The policy references "administrative regulations" multiple times but no AR 4040 exists to provide the procedural details.</description>
            <missing_from>AR</missing_from>

            <legal_basis>
                <california_code>
                    <citation>Education Code Section 35160</citation>
                    <text>The governing board of any school district may initiate and carry on any program, activity, or may otherwise act in any manner which is not in conflict with or inconsistent with, or preempted by, any law and which is not in conflict with the purposes for which school districts are established.</citation>
                </california_code>
            </legal_basis>

            <required_language>
                <text>An Administrative Regulation should be created to include: specific procedures for technology access and account management; detailed acceptable use agreement requirements; step-by-step monitoring and enforcement procedures; specific disciplinary action protocols; cybersecurity incident response procedures; professional development implementation details; and procedures for handling technology misuse reports.</text>
            </required_language>

            <recommended_placement>AR</recommended_placement>
        </issue>

        <issue priority="MATERIAL" confidence="90">
            <title>Missing Specific Data Privacy and Student Information Protection Procedures</title>
            <description>While the policy mentions not sharing confidential student records with third parties like AI apps "except as permitted by law," there are no specific procedures detailing what constitutes permissible sharing, data encryption requirements, or compliance with FERPA and California Student Privacy Acts. Given the increasing use of AI and cloud-based technologies, specific data protection procedures are essential.</description>
            <missing_from>BOTH</missing_from>

            <legal_basis>
                <california_code>
                    <citation>Education Code Section 49073.1</citation>
                    <text>A school service provider shall not knowingly engage in targeted advertising to students or families based on any information the school service provider has acquired because of the use of that operator's site, service, or application for school purposes.</citation>
                </california_code>
            </legal_basis>

            <required_language>
                <text>Specific procedures must be established for: (1) determining when student data sharing with technology services is permitted; (2) required data encryption and security standards; (3) vendor compliance verification procedures; (4) data breach notification protocols; and (5) regular auditing of third-party technology services handling student data.</text>
            </required_language>

            <recommended_placement>AR</recommended_placement>
        </issue>

        <issue priority="MATERIAL" confidence="80">
            <title>Missing Specific AI Use Guidelines and Restrictions</title>
            <description>While the policy mentions AI apps and requires employees to review final products, there are no specific guidelines about which AI tools are approved, prohibited AI uses, or procedures for evaluating new AI technologies. Given the rapid evolution of AI technology and potential risks, more detailed guidance is needed.</description>
            <missing_from>BOTH</missing_from>

            <legal_basis>
                <california_code>
                    <citation>Education Code Section 51512</citation>
                    <text>Requires districts to ensure instructional materials and methods are appropriate and do not violate student privacy or safety requirements.</citation>
                </california_code>
            </legal_basis>

            <required_language>
                <text>Specific procedures should include: (1) list of approved AI tools and services; (2) prohibited AI applications (e.g., those that store student data inappropriately); (3) evaluation criteria for new AI tools; (4) specific restrictions on AI use with student information; and (5) procedures for reporting AI-related concerns or incidents.</text>
            </required_language>

            <recommended_placement>AR</recommended_placement>
        </issue>

        <issue priority="MINOR" confidence="75">
            <title>Missing Social Media Use Guidelines</title>
            <description>The policy addresses general technology use but lacks specific guidance on employee use of social media platforms for professional purposes, which has become increasingly common for educational communication and professional development.</description>
            <missing_from>BOTH</missing_from>

            <legal_basis>
                <california_code>
                    <citation>Education Code Section 44050</citation>
                    <text>Requires certificated employees to maintain professional standards and conduct that reflects positively on the profession.</citation>
                </california_code>
            </legal_basis>

            <required_language>
                <text>Guidelines should address: (1) appropriate professional use of social media; (2) restrictions on connecting with current students on personal social media accounts; (3) professional communication standards on social platforms; and (4) procedures for handling inappropriate social media interactions.</text>
            </required_language>

            <recommended_placement>AR</recommended_placement>
        </issue>
    </compliance_issues>
</compliance_report>
